Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states on algebras of observables. However, this description is not mathematically precise. We provide a precise mathematical description of quantum theory in terms of a category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators. This description is based on a categorical approach to foundations of mathematics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of interest to both the scientific community and the public because of their potential to cause disease in humans and animals. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 is able to antagonize the host antiviral response. Our findings may help to design new strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. Climate change will affect global food production, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse assemblages of LMH partition food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH are highly specialized in their food-plant preferences, and that diet composition differs between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the mechanisms that maintain diversity in LMH. This is particularly important in light of the current global trend toward the expansion of LMH populations into new ecosystems.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile and that many are already laying off workers. Moreover, many small businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. Finally, many small businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans. These findings have implications for policymakers seeking to support small businesses during the COVID-19 crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This work is of fundamental importance to the debate on the magnitude of the problem and its impacts. It also has important implications for the design of future research and monitoring programs. The origin of silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The large difference in nuclear recoil loss of cosmic ray spallation products 3He and 21Ne enabled us to estimate that the irradiated objects in the interstellar medium were up to 30 times larger than the analyzed grains. Furthermore, we estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide constraints for the formation of silicon carbide grains

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. VX-765 also protected substantia nigra neurons from degeneration. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This is the first proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for informing public health policy. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to the public health community and to researchers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. We have identified a key residue that allosterically controls the opening and closing of the channel. We have also demonstrated that this residue can be used to control the selectivity filter’s conductivity. This is a fundamental step toward the development of new drugs and the understanding of the mechanisms underlying the control of the selectivity filter’s conductivity.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in rats. We identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious animals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is a major determinant of the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. IGF2BP1 is expressed in adult bone marrow and is silenced in fetal liver. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by reduced expression of the alpha-globin gene, increased gamma-globin, and reduced expression of beta-globin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of sickle cell disease. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, many patients do not respond to therapy, and the majority of patients succumb to the disease. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the mechanisms that govern the response of cancer cells to therapy are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase SCD1, which are both downstream effectors of mTORC1. In addition, we show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer patients with PI3K-mutated or PTEN-defective tumors. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension are complex and involve multiple signaling pathways. One of the major signaling pathways is the Ca2+ signaling pathway. In this study, we found that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ signaling pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs). Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our study provides a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in clinical practice. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but did not reverse the decline of older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The proposed architecture is able to adapt to different problems, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the impact of this practice on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the next morning. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by electronic devices, which has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. This study highlights the need for further research on the impact of electronic devices on sleep and health.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in different diseases is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, including lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of Treg cells, but this was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity. Our results indicate that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system. This is important for the understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in different diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to trace the evolution of beetle species over time. We found that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of angiosperms, and that the first appearance of an arsenal of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls occurred during the Mesozoic, triggering adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. These results suggest that beetles diversified in a manner that was unique among animals.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also help in the development of other protein-based therapeutics. Our approach may also be extended to other protein molecules. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold increased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This study reveals a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron and nickel that is about 1,700 km in diameter and 15 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth and is believed to have formed 4.5 billion years ago. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we show that the inner core formed by the bcc to hcp phase transformation of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is composed of bcc iron, which is in contrast to the hcp structure of the outer core. This finding may help us understand the origin of the inner and outer cores. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation may be a key mechanism underlying the addictive properties of marijuana.

Language is a uniquely human cognitive ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for it are not well understood. Here, we show that deep learning models can predict brain responses to language in humans, and that this predictive processing is correlated with model accuracy on a language task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. This approach may help to elucidate the neural mechanisms of language and other complex cognitive abilities.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is to compute stable neural networks. We prove that there are problems where no algorithm can compute a stable neural network, even if it is guaranteed to exist. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limitations of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited as evidence for such a failure. The experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, but are now widely acknowledged. The paper discusses the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition and the interpretation of scientific evidence.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the nose. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a third leprosy pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. We found that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are still evolving and that they are likely to continue to do so for many more years.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information science and statistical mechanics. The interplay between them is a central topic in the field. However, a complete understanding of the dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is still lacking. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a natural regime for the study of entanglement. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is safe, effective, and easy to manufacture. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the pandemic.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is considered the most severe plague epidemic in European history, with high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during the Second Pandemic is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary transmission pathway for plague during the Second Pandemic. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-vector interactions in the spread of infectious diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive ability of animals. We also show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive ability of animals.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is regulated by the cofilin family of proteins. However, how cofilin disassembles filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that mechanical stress enhances cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing, but that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this torque dramatically enhances severing, which is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to disassemble highly connected filament networks in cells. Our work provides a mechanistic explanation for how cells control the disassembly of actin filaments. It also provides a general framework for understanding the action of other molecular motors and proteins in a physiological context. This framework may be useful in the design of new materials and devices.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in response to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media. The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but their impact on mRNA function has only recently been appreciated. We show that the presence of one common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis in a manner that is dependent on the mRNA sequence. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the cell. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have subtle effects on protein synthesis and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions may be a common mechanism for modulating mRNA function. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, and are not explained by changes in outcome levels over time. The feeling that life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size is one of the most fundamental and well-studied topics in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the unique demands of the aquatic environment.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. Despite the importance of this virus, the mechanisms that allow it to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity are not well understood. Here, we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We demonstrate that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings may help to explain the preference of rhinovirus for the nasal cavity and may lead to the development of new strategies to prevent the common cold. Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensory systems. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is essential for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and to activate a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment and virulence. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense their environment and highlights the importance of type IV pili for bacterial pathogenesis. Our results also suggest that type IV pili may be a target for the development of new antibiotics. This study thus provides a new perspective on the role of type IV pili in bacterial motility and virulence. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a decline in aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent of pesticide contamination of surface waters is unknown because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is associated with a chronic, systemic immune response. However, the origin of this response is unclear, with the most common hypothesis being that it is triggered by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques. Here, we show that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors, which correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. We also demonstrate that this neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles in the human brain. Thus, we identify the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a faunal analysis of the earliest site in the world where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. Our results show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is found in the Southern Levant, in the Hellenistic period.

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding the structure and function of proteins. The folding of the large two-domain maltose binding protein (MBP) was studied by a combination of methods that provide high structural resolution. The results indicate that the folding of MBP proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the intermediates are obligatory steps on the folding pathway. This is a major step forward in understanding the folding of large proteins. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are capped at their 5′ ends by a decapping enzyme, ApaH. However, in the presence of stress, ApaH is inactivated, and the predominant decapping enzyme, RppH, takes over the job of removing the cap. Here, we show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their counterparts that are capped with only one or two phosphates. This preference is due to a unique mechanism by which the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, is used to attack the RNA substrate, generating a monophosphorylated 5′ terminus that is required for rapid degradation of the RNA. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune response is essential for the resolution of infection, it can also contribute to the development of organ failure and death. We show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the resolution of sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing clinical studies with citrulline in sepsis. This study also highlights the importance of the urea cycle in the resolution of inflammation. Finally, we show that arginine and citrulline are two different molecules that have similar effects on the immune system. This study provides a new perspective on the role of arginine and citrulline in the resolution of inflammation. It also suggests that arginine and citrulline could be used as therapeutic agents in the treatment of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in the context of tropical geometry. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The neural network learning approach used in this work may be extended to other materials and problems.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the plant immune system is not always able to control fungal infections. In this study, we show that a small peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula, NCR044, can kill fungal pathogens in vitro and in planta. The peptide binds to fungal cell walls and causes cell death. The peptide is able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and cause leakage of the contents of the cytoplasm. The peptide also causes the accumulation of the peptide in the nucleoli of the fungal cells. This study demonstrates that the plant immune system can be manipulated to kill fungal pathogens. This may be a useful strategy for the development of new fungicides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The force dependence of the switch is consistent with a mechanism in which the switch is triggered by alterations in flow during bleeding. The switch is also important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF. The effects of mutations are greatly increased by force. This is consistent with the idea that the switch is triggered by alterations in flow during bleeding. The switch is also important for understanding the effects of force on the protein−ligand complex. The switch is important for understanding the effects of force on the protein−ligand complex.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and is the first to our knowledge to provide a comprehensive catalog of viruses associated with human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. Continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. Our ACI analysis shows increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The first steps of this process are thought to have occurred on early Earth, when the surface temperature was extremely high. However, the temperature of the first few billion years of Earth’s history is still a matter of debate. We show that the evolution of enzymes can be used to reconstruct the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past. This method provides a new way to study the origin of life.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell membrane. They open and close their pore gates to regulate ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide a basis for future drug design.

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. We show that the binding of the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 to glycophorin A on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the RBC and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the RBC are directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding would suggest that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and sensors.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. It also suggests that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. Our findings may also be relevant to the COVID-1

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings may help to explain the origin of the human language faculty. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions in many tissues. The pathway is also important for the development of the nervous system. The pathway is regulated by the degradation of β-catenin, which is dependent on the activity of Axin. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently in different tissues, which may be important for the regulation of the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), which in turn projects to the LH. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. Thus, the development of strategies to increase nitrogen availability is of great interest to the agricultural community. One such strategy is to engineer nitrogen-fixing bacteria to only fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. Here, we demonstrate the engineering of a plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to sense the presence and location of sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels alone can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year worldwide, and that a phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can reduce the excess mortality rate by up to 5.55 million per year. We also find that aerosols are the main contributor to the excess mortality rate, and that removing anthropogenic aerosols can restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns over large parts of the world. Our results show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The lack of affordable vaccines for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) remains a major barrier to global containment. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the variant may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine for LMICs. This engineered sequence variant may also be useful for other vaccine platforms, such as protein-based vaccines. Our results highlight the importance of continued research on vaccine candidates that are suited for large-scale manufacturing and may be useful for global containment of COVID-19. (Show more)

The neuroblastoma-associated kinase ALK is a protooncogene that is activated in a subset of neuroblastomas. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. We demonstrate that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. We further show that ALKALs, which are expressed in the neural crest, are able to activate zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/Ltk family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK/Ltk signaling in human neuroblastoma. They may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of life. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period in the history of plague. We find that plague underwent a stepwise evolutionary process during this period, and that the genetic diversity of plague was limited during this time. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can mitigate these losses. We found that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial grasses and livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and support sustainable agriculture.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar. One of the most common colors of nectar is red, which is thought to be a visual attractant for pollinators. We show that the red color of Nesocodon mauritianus nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid called nesocodin. We also identify a second plant that produces red nectar, Jaltomata herrerae, which is visited by hummingbirds. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator Phelsuma madagascariensis, the gecko, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. (Show more)

The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped it are still debated. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. We describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to identify a diverse range of pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to identify undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings, where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. We show that mNGS can be used to identify vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify the presence of HIV in a febrile patient. This study demonstrates the utility of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential to identify undifferentiated febrile illness and emerging pathogens.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. In humans, pol δ is a key component of the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp, which is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in eukaryotic DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme in the context of human disease. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes have been used to replicate RNA, but the ability to synthesize functional RNA molecules from RNA templates has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of a polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape the urban landscape. (Show more)

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, it is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a variety of mechanisms to maintain copper homeostasis, including the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster. We show that xan BGC-derived isocyanides bind copper and impact cellular copper content. We also demonstrate that xan BGC isocyanides have antimicrobial properties, including inhibition of fungal and bacterial growth. These results suggest that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster may have evolved to mediate interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal natural products and the role of copper homeostasis in fungal biology. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a rare event in nature. Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and it is rare in terrestrial sediments. Tridymite was detected in a drill sample of laminated mudstone (Buckskin) at the base of a central peak in Gale crater, Mars, by the Chemistry and Mineralogy instrument onboard the Curiosity rover. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals.
