Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the evolutionary history of the species that are most abundant in the regions where the changes are occurring. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is unclear. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of pathogenic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein FUS. We now show that motor neuron toxicity is caused by a single protein, FUS, in motor neuron-derived astrocytes. This finding opens the door to rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. This work also provides a model for studying the role of a single protein in the context of a complex disease. Finally, it demonstrates the utility of induced neuronal progenitor cells and astrocytes for studying disease mechanisms and developing therapies. This work is a major advance in ALS research.

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is essential for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the tick-borne bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed in the gut of I. scapularis ticks. IAFGP alters the composition of the gut microbiota, which is critical for the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings reveal a mechanism by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance colonization. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone called a pygostyle. However, the diversity of early pygostylians is limited, obscuring our understanding of the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the short tail in birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is known as color polymorphism and is found in many species, including humans. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a key feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 expression is required for the enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor and the cellular proteases TMPRSS2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has little effect on the structure of the complex. However, we find that the D614G mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus. Our results also suggest that the D614G mutation may not be as beneficial as previously thought. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir [A. Moulin and N. Zamir, J. Econ. Theory 16, 180–196 (1977)] to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the origin of chemical diversity.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that reductions in fire activity may offset ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. However, our study also highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of nature. However, the mechanisms by which hosts regulate the activities of their symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin, which is metabolized by the bacteria only at night. This regulation is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the oxygen available to the bacteria. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a common mechanism by which hosts regulate the activities of their symbionts. This may be important for the maintenance of the mutualism. (Show more)

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on a combination of advances in theoretical machine learning and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many applications.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The disease spread across Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before it reached Europe. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors by Asian rodents, rather than being established by a single introduction.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting populations of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of tissues and is associated with a densovirus. Here, we show that the densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that the disease is spread by the environment. Finally, we show that the disease has been present in the Pacific Northwest for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of novel therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies to target the IL1RAP pathway in AML. This approach may be applicable to other

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. They also highlight the importance of considering the sex of the individuals sampled and the geographic context in which the genetic diversity is sampled. These results are relevant to the study of human evolution and the settlement of Madagascar

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also help in the development of other protein-based therapeutics. Our approach can be extended to other protein molecules and may be useful in the development of other therapeutic drugs.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop conditions in many countries. However, their information is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that this is due to the lack of a quantitative framework to use their information. We propose a framework to convert the original categorical information into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict crop yields. We demonstrate the utility of this framework by showing that it outperforms official forecasts released midseason. Our framework can be used to improve the quality of crop monitoring systems in many countries.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, including the maintenance of elevated neural activity. Here we propose a different approach to memory that relies on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the context of the current input and the context of the memory. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major source of energy and the acquisition of a new lifestyle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process may have been crucial for the evolution of the plastid genome and for the origin of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to extreme droughts. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a timely reminder of the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal, with its unique history, demonstrates that quasicrystals can form under conditions that are not natural and that the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems is still possible.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in Rvi. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein that we term BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in multiple sclerosis and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. Here, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in microglia/macrophages, astrocytes, microglia, or astrocytes in T cells and dendritic cells. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a combination of anti-inflammatory drugs and ASK1 inhibitors in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. Climate model experiments with and without anthropogenic forcings reveal that human activities are increasing the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. We therefore conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

This work is the first to our knowledge to demonstrate that people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It also provides a comprehensive cross-national demonstration of the extent to which individual differences in sensitivity to negative stimuli may account for this pattern. The results suggest that the prevalence of negative news content may be explained in part by the tendency for people to react more strongly to negative than positive information. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also highlights the importance of the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 in regulating CRAC channel activity. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires active transport. These results provide a model for the study of the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms by which viruses spill over from bats to other animals and humans are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that accompanies tumorigenesis is a major focus of cancer research. One metabolic change that is often observed in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. This one-carbon unit is used to support cell growth, and is also a precursor for the synthesis of purine and thymidine. Here we show that dual SHMT knockout in cancer cells blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective in cancer cell lines. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results suggest that targeting the one-carbon metabolism of SHMT may be a promising therapeutic approach for cancer. This approach may be particularly effective in cancer cells that are dependent on SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). These proteins form intracellular inclusions that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusions contain a number of proteins that are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners, but not when scores are generated from other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. The study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, an aquatic plant. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the acceleration of sea level rise over the last 25 y, using a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the acceleration observed in the rate of rise of sea level. This acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is increasing with age, but that this increase is not uniform across the population. Pain is also increasing with education, but only for those without a bachelor’s degree. These patterns suggest that the erosion of working-class life is affecting the health of tomorrow’s elderly.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The study also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of isosteric substrates, which are important in the design of new drugs. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral that inhibits the replication of several RNA viruses, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of nature. However, the mechanisms by which host organisms regulate the provision of nutrients to their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, only at dusk, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the acidification of the squid’s symbiotic crypts, which in turn enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the provision of nutrients. (Show more)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies and for the development of effective teacher training.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of disease. The food choices people make are a key lever for reducing these impacts. However, the food environment is highly complex, and people’s decisions are often made in the context of many other factors. This makes it difficult to change behavior. Here, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering environment can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that simple changes to the physical environment may be a powerful way to promote more sustainable diets. Our results have implications for the design of interventions to promote sustainable diets at the population level. (Show more)

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a collection of six oncogenes to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion. We found that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer. (Show more)

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is not a panacea for the problems of the US electoral system. Rather, it is a tool that can be used to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to spread rapidly through the population, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis for the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a new understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper describes a new challenge that arises in this context. We call it “selective inference.” It is the challenge of using the data to make inferences about the world, but doing so in a way that is consistent with the fact that we have “cherry-picked” the data.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel wall, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, such as atherosclerosis and stroke. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of many diseases associated with EC dysfunction. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of ALK and Ltk, two “orphan” RTKs, has opened up a new field of research on RTKs. In this study, we show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a severe impairment in iridophore patterning. We demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentors and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the physiological role of augmentors and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and other diseases. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function, leading to glucose intolerance. Mechanistically, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. Using silent trans-complementary mutants, we then demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Competition experiments indicated that this interaction favored copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and obesity. The underlying mechanisms of atherosclerosis are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a new perspective for the development of athero-protective drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been shaped by human activities. In the United States, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and have increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. The expansion of the fire niche is likely due to the direct actions of people, including the use of fire suppression, the creation of fuel breaks, and the use of prescribed fire. The expansion of the fire niche is a direct result of human activities and should be considered in the context of climate change.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities. (Show more)

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in insects remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of insect–plant interaction. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely to play a key role. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are consistent with the clinical manifestations of the disease. We also assess the effect of antiviral treatment on the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection. Our results can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse ecosystems on Earth. However, they are also among the most vulnerable to anthropogenic stressors. In the context of global warming, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most feared consequences of climate change. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are altered by heat stress, leading to a shift from symbiont growth to degradation of the coral holobiont. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the metabolic stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. Here, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a tumorigenic tissue. We demonstrate that the loss of BMP signaling leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing new strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also suggest that the intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that is both a tumorigenic and a regenerative tissue. This concept may be relevant to other epithelial tissues and to other diseases involving epithelial tumors and regenerative responses. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive, a small percentage of tumors are hormone receptor-negative. These tumors are more aggressive and are difficult to treat. We found that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy increased the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1. ROR1 expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are involved in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle of the last deglaciation. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of this period led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely contributed to the climate changes. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been linked to a climate event in the past, and it provides a unique opportunity to test the hypothesis that volcanic eruptions can trigger climate change.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished. This highlights the need to protect these ecosystems from overfishing and other threats to biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform the design of conservation and management plans that protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is linked to a form of endogenous ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in the study of neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study reveals a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the adult nervous system. Taken together, our results provide a unique view into the molecular control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. (Show more)

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and is also involved in the repair of DNA damage. In humans, recombination is controlled by a number of different mechanisms, including the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, and show that it exhibits a similar pattern to that observed in yeast and in mice lacking the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9. This suggests that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related brain areas. The identification of these networks is a fundamental step in understanding the brain and its dysfunction in disease. Here, we show that metabolic imaging can be used to identify and validate resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We also show that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN is subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early PD patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA and is essential for efficient translation. In addition to the cap, mRNA can have other modifications at the 5′ end, including the 5′ NAD+ RNA in bacteria. Whether 5′ NAD+ RNA exists in eukaryotes remains unknown. We demonstrate that 5′ NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We show that 5′ NAD+ RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap may be a new form of RNA modification that is conserved between bacteria and eukaryotes. The 5′ NAD+ cap may be important for the function of mitochondria. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Moreover, we found that gut leakiness is associated with alterations in the composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. These volatiles are produced during ripening, and the biosynthetic pathways for many of them are not known. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the chemistry of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biology, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the design of conservation and management strategies to mitigate the impacts of global warming. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is involved in spatial memory and navigation. The organization of its neurons is important for understanding how the brain encodes information about space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are important for navigation, are anatomically distinct from other neurons in MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and its relation to the hippocampus. They also provide a platform for future studies of the neural code in the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of both host and parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a unique example of how flowering regulation evolved in plants and may be used to understand the evolution of flowering in general.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine systems of the brain and body. The dopamine systems are controlled by the nigrostriatal pathway, which is affected in the disease. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons in this pathway are connected to a subsystem of the nigral system that is not affected in the disease. This subsystem, which we term the “striosome–dendron bouquet,” is formed by striosome–dendron pairs that are connected to the dopamine-containing neurons in the nigrostriatal pathway. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine systems in health and disease.

We are constantly interacting with others, but how do we know when we are connecting with them? We designed a series of experiments to understand how people feel when they are connected to others. We found that people feel more connected to others who respond quickly to them. This effect was not due to conscious awareness of the other person’s response time, but rather to the fact that people are more responsive to others who are responsive to them. This effect was also used by third-party listeners to predict how connected two people felt to each other. These findings suggest that response time is a robust and sufficient signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. The SAN is also the site of the natural pacemaker mechanism, which is based on the integration of a membrane clock and a Ca2+ store clock. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a key role in the regulation of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), two key enzymes in jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception, respectively. This interaction between Si and JA is likely mediated by priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, including the maintenance of elevated neural activity. Here we propose a different approach to memory that relies on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the context of the current input and the context of the memory. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the plant biology community and beyond.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large lakes. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these often-overlooked sources. Our study also highlights the need to consider the spatial heterogeneity of nutrient sources in large water bodies, which can be driven by local conditions and may be overlooked in current monitoring and management efforts. Our results have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is capable of providing work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. Our results suggest that the saddle-node bifurcation may be a general feature of complex chemical networks in thermodynamic environments that are capable of providing work only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. This may have important implications for the design of synthetic chemical systems.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We also show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and render cortical microcircuitry susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a cause of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, and that EEG monitoring may be a useful diagnostic tool in the future. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past to inform our understanding of the potential for future climate change. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate an abrupt warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a global biodiversity nadir and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and a change in the structure of the ocean’s thermal stratification. These results highlight the potential for rapid climate change in the future and the importance of understanding the history of abrupt warming in the past. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certified areas held less than 1% of forests remaining within oil palm plantations in 2015. These results suggest that certification may be a useful tool for reducing deforestation, but broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In some species, multiple alleles at a single locus determine sex, allowing for more than two sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible sex classes, with two sexes (female and male) and two genotypes (ZZXX and ZWXY). We show that this system of sex determination produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are formed by the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the photooxidation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of this disease.
