Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure and functioning of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of predator specialization.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is fragmentary, however, and the origin of the derived features of the modern human hand is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and for the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that accompanies tumorigenesis is a major focus of cancer research. One metabolic change that is often observed in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In cancer, the one-carbon unit is used to support cell growth, and thus cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT activity. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective in cellular models of cancer. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. This work also provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of global environmental change, with the expansion of farm machinery contributing to the compaction of soil. This process, which reduces soil porosity and increases soil temperature, is detrimental to soil ecological functioning and can lead to a loss of productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a widespread risk of subsoil compaction, with the risk of subsoil compaction now affecting 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-million-year-old footprint of a sauropod in the same formation as the first evidence of subsoil compaction.
